title: Forest Tables
text: causal-based studies, tend look covariates may modify relationship exposure outcome. approach stratified interaction analyses. help visualize , create grouped forest plot. toy data set, use lung dataset survival package. toy variables : age = primary exposure sex = strata interaction term time = survival time pat.karno = Karnofsky score (activity/performance status) uses two packages meant implicitly contain information terms, go implementation details . note, toy example easibly scaled dozens variables many orders using arcana volundr package.
code: head(survival::lung) #>   inst time status age sex ph.ecog ph.karno pat.karno meal.cal wt.loss #> 1    3  306      2  74   1       1       90       100     1175      NA #> 2    3  455      2  68   1       0       90        90     1225      15 #> 3    3 1010      1  56   1       0       90        90       NA      15 #> 4    5  210      2  57   1       1       90        60     1150      11 #> 5    1  883      2  60   1       0      100        90       NA       0 #> 6   12 1022      1  74   1       1       50        80      513       0  # Modifying lung to make estimates more pronounced lung$age_z <- scale(lung$age) lung$pat.karno_z <- scale(lung$pat.karno)   # Inital model f <- Surv(time, status) ~ age_z + pat.karno_z + sex m <- coxph(f, data = lung) summary(m) #> Call: #> coxph(formula = f, data = lung) #>  #>   n= 225, number of events= 162  #>    (3 observations deleted due to missingness) #>  #>                 coef exp(coef) se(coef)      z Pr(>|z|)     #> age_z        0.10700   1.11294  0.08466  1.264 0.206269     #> pat.karno_z -0.27873   0.75674  0.08244 -3.381 0.000722 *** #> sex         -0.51926   0.59496  0.16897 -3.073 0.002118 **  #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #>  #>             exp(coef) exp(-coef) lower .95 upper .95 #> age_z          1.1129     0.8985    0.9428    1.3138 #> pat.karno_z    0.7567     1.3215    0.6438    0.8895 #> sex            0.5950     1.6808    0.4272    0.8285 #>  #> Concordance= 0.639  (se = 0.025 ) #> Likelihood ratio test= 24.33  on 3 df,   p=2e-05 #> Wald test            = 23.72  on 3 df,   p=3e-05 #> Score (logrank) test = 24.23  on 3 df,   p=2e-05

title: Forest Tables
text: Now, let’s reconsider subgroups based sex. can fit data, place organized/informative table. forged table basis functions package, allowing us flexibility retrieve information models. core function several parameters may need additional explanation. Please see documentation via ?tbl_group_forests. can see strata sex, forest plots scaled automatically. next example, control axis help show data clearly. Now, interaction, can add p.value interaction effect, well adjust axis . Note confidence intervals symmetrical around central point , x-axis log scale.
code: f <- fmls(     Surv(time, status) ~ X(age_z) + pat.karno_z + S(sex),     label = list(age ~ "Age (SD)", sex ~ "Sex", pat.karno ~ "Karnofsky Score (SD)") )  # Create formula in preparation for stratification # Note that sex is not included in the formula here print(f) #> <fmls[1]> #> Surv(time, status) ~ age_z + pat.karno_z m <- fit(f, .fit = coxph, robust = TRUE, ties = "breslow", data = lung, archetype = TRUE)   # Here we can see that there are now two models for the strata we indicated print(m) #> <model_archetype[2]> #> coxph(Surv(time, status) ~ age_z + pat.karno_z) #> coxph(Surv(time, status) ~ age_z + pat.karno_z)  # Into a model table x <- mdls(sex_strata = m) print(x) #> <forge> #>   model   type  subtype name      subname descr…¹ number formula outcome expos…² #>   <list>  <chr> <chr>   <chr>     <chr>   <chr>    <int> <chr>   <chr>   <chr>   #> 1 <coxph> coxph NA      sex_stra… f_1_ST… NA           1 Surv(t… Surv(t… age_z   #> 2 <coxph> coxph NA      sex_stra… f_1_ST… NA           1 Surv(t… Surv(t… age_z   #> # … with 8 more variables: mediator <chr>, interaction <chr>, strata <chr>, #> #   level <chr>, terms <rnls>, model_info <md_info>, #> #   parameter_estimates <par_est>, run <lgl>, and abbreviated variable names #> #   ¹​description, ²​exposure tbl_group_forests(     # Forge object     object = x,     # Notes outcome ~ exposure relationship     formula = Surv(time, status) ~ age_z,      # Stratification variable     vars = "sex",      # If TRUE, would look for interaction terms instead     interaction = FALSE,      # Describes what information we want to see on each model     columns = list(beta ~ "Hazard Ratio", conf ~ "95% CI", n ~ "No.", p ~ "P Value"),     # Modifications for the forest plot itself      axis = list(title ~ "Forest Plot", lab ~ "HR (95% CI)", scale ~ "continuous", int ~ 1) ) #> Warning in cond & tbl$locname != "title": longer object length is not a multiple #> of shorter object length #> Warning in cond & tbl$locname != "subtitle": longer object length is not a #> multiple of shorter object length m <-     rx(Surv(time, status) ~ X(age_z) + pat.karno_z + In(sex)) |>     sx(label = list(age ~ "Age (SD)", sex ~ "Sex", pat.karno ~ "Karnofsky Score (SD)")) |>     fmls() |>     fit(.fit = coxph, robust = TRUE, ties = "breslow", data = lung, archetype = TRUE)  #> Recreating interaction term with the specified exposure(s).  # Shows the new interaction term that found itself with the key exposure print(m) #> <model_archetype[1]> #> coxph(Surv(time, status) ~ age_z + pat.karno_z + sex + age_z:sex)  # Create the table x <- mdls(sex_interaction = m) print(x) #> <forge> #>   model   type  subtype name      subname descr…¹ number formula outcome expos…² #>   <list>  <chr> <chr>   <chr>     <chr>   <chr>    <int> <chr>   <chr>   <chr>   #> 1 <coxph> coxph NA      sex_inte… fmls(sx NA           1 Surv(t… Surv(t… age_z   #> # … with 8 more variables: mediator <chr>, interaction <chr>, strata <chr>, #> #   level <chr>, terms <rnls>, model_info <md_info>, #> #   parameter_estimates <par_est>, run <lgl>, and abbreviated variable names #> #   ¹​description, ²​exposure tbl_group_forests(     # Forge object     object = x,     formula = Surv(time, status) ~ age_z,      vars = "sex",      interaction = TRUE,      columns = list(beta ~ "Hazard Ratio", conf ~ "95% CI", n ~ "No.", p ~ "P Value"),     axis = list(title ~ "Forest Plot", lab ~ "HR (95% CI)", scale ~ "log", int ~ 1, breaks ~ c(0, 1, 2), lim ~ c(0.5, 2)) ) #> Warning in cond & tbl$locname != "title": longer object length is not a multiple #> of shorter object length #> Warning in cond & tbl$locname != "subtitle": longer object length is not a #> multiple of shorter object length

title: Cutting through Many Models
text: goal durandal cut many models understand relationships key terms. “big data” numerous modeling options , trouble understanding relationship variables play different roles explaining causal pie.

title: Cutting through Many Models
text: can install development version durandal like :

what: durandal: Causal Chains and Connections — durandal-package
title: durandal: Causal Chains and Connections — durandal-package
durandal: Causal Chains and Connections — durandal-package
Grouped Forest Plots — tbl_group_forests
code: tbl_group_forests(   object,   formula = formula(),   vars = character(),   columns = list(beta ~ "Estimate", conf ~ "95% CI", n ~ "No."),   flip = FALSE,   interaction = FALSE,   axis = list(scale ~ "continuous"),   width = list() )

title: Grouped Forest Plots — tbl_group_forests
text: object forge object contains represents model data, required grouping variables (strata interaction terms). formula Identifies relationships interest, LHS representing outcome, RHS representing exposure. vars Character vector variables interest. can either grouping variables, can performed interaction terms (based models included originally). parameter interaction changed TRUE, create joint confidence intervals presence absence interaction term. columns Additional columns help describe subgroup models. least one column selected list. sequence listed reflect sequence shown table. current options : beta = point estimate value, odds ratio hazard ratio conf = inclusion confidence interval (presumed 95%-ile) n = number observations model group p = p.value model interaction term example: list(beta ~ "Hazard", conf ~ "95% CI" n ~ ".")" flip Determine odds hazard ratio shown reciprocal values. Instead decreasing hazard every unit increase, describes increasing hazard every unit decrease. interaction Logical value identify model attempt use interaction terms . Currently accepts binary/dichotomous variables interaction term. axis Argument help modify forest plot . list-formula following parameters. named, function attempt "guess" optimal parameters. options : title = label title column describing forest plot lim = x-axis limits breaks = x-axis tick marks break points numbers int = x-axis intercept lab = label x-axis scale = defaults continuous, may also use log transformation well c("continuous", "log") example: list(title ~ "Decreasing Hazard", lab ~ "HR (95% CI)) width Describes width column list two-sided formulas. RHS decimal reflecting percent column take entire table. forest plot usually given 30% width. example: list(n ~ .1, forest ~ 0.3)

what: Compact and minimal theme for gt tables — theme_gt_compact
title: Compact and minimal theme for gt tables — theme_gt_compact
text: theme used placing somewhat larger tables xaringan slides making spacing compact decreasing font size. exposed variables control font size table width, option gt package allowed.

title: Compact and minimal theme for gt tables — theme_gt_compact
Compact and minimal theme for gt tables — theme_gt_compact
text: data table object created using gt() function. table.width width table. Can specified single-length character units pixels percentage. provided single-length numeric vector, assumed value given units pixels. px() pct() helper functions can also used pass numeric values obtain values pixel percent units. ... passing additional arguments tab_options() function
